metadata.metaValue: First we create some geometry that can create a snow shadow. Plug your own geometry into pass_input_geometry.

This is our "down" vector along which snow falls. 

We use it both to raycast looking for areas in snow shadows, as well as 
testing against the normal of the meshes.

As the last step, we mesh our particles. 

This is by far the most expensive part of this process,
and by disabling this a faster preview is possible

An example that uses ray-casting to create snow-shadows, then scatters particles and creates snow. Snow does not collect under things, and the snow direction is customizable. 

This example contains multi-sampled ray casting, scattering points, transfering data from a mesh, and meshing points.
